document: Chapter 9: Firewalls and Intrusion Prevention Systems - Computer Security: Principles and Practice, 4th Edition

questions.question: A firewall is a single point of control between a trusted network and an untrusted network.
Firewalls are only used to block outgoing traffic.
A firewall's access policy is based on the organization's security risk assessment.
Packet filtering firewalls inspect the content of application data.
A default discard policy is more secure than a default forward policy.
Stateful inspection firewalls track the state of active connections.
Application-level gateways require proxy code for each application.
Circuit-level gateways operate at the network layer.
A bastion host is a hardened system used as a security platform.
Host-based firewalls protect entire networks, not individual hosts.
Personal firewalls are typically hardware devices.
An IPS can block malicious traffic, while an IDS only detects it.
HIPS stands for Host Intrusion Prevention System.
HIPS can use signature-based and anomaly-based detection.
A sandbox approach is used to run and monitor untrusted code.
NIPS stands for Network Intrusion Prevention System.
NIPS can modify or discard packets in real-time.
The Digital Immune System was developed only by Microsoft.
Snort Inline allows Snort to function as an IPS.
A DMZ network is located behind the internal firewall only.
Firewalls can prevent all types of malware attacks.
Packet filters are vulnerable to IP spoofing attacks.
Application gateways are transparent to end users.
SOCKS is a circuit-level gateway protocol.
A personal firewall cannot monitor outgoing traffic.
An IPS uses only signature-based detection.
HIPS can protect system calls and file system access.
NIPS requires deep packet inspection.
The Digital Immune System analyzes malware globally.
Snort Inline can modify packets instead of dropping them.
Firewalls are obsolete due to modern encryption.
Stateful firewalls are slower than packet filters.
A bastion host runs only essential services.
HIPS is only effective for servers, not desktops.
NIPS can reassemble application payloads.
Unified Threat Management products combine multiple security functions.
Firewalls are not needed if an organization uses VPNs.
Anomaly detection looks for known attack patterns.
A circuit-level gateway verifies the legitimacy of TCP handshakes.
Personal firewalls are unnecessary on corporate networks.
